metadata.name: fabrics #11
metadata.description:
'fabrics' explores textile art made with code mixing different patterns of very small lines.

Inspiration from Anni Albers works, Antoni T√†pies and Studio Yorktown for the patterns and the colours. Also oriental rugs and clothes from around the world had been used for the palettes.
Palettes: Monochrome, Kilt, Kilim, Austral, Peruvian, Afghan, Berber, Nain, Fur, Jeans, Kente, Bogolan, Albers, Sabler.

Press [s] to save an 1200x1360 image (.png).
Click on it to change the orientation of the stitches.

Generative art made using p5js. By @mehno_art

metadata.name: Sketch Book #44
metadata.description:
Sketch Book is a generative collection that imagines an abstract sketch built with lines and shapes in harmony with each other.

It‚Äôs called Sketch Book as it started with me sketching a bunch of lines in p5.js and then warping them to give them a natural waviness. The artwork combines subdivision and domain warping techniques before drawing the final lines and shapes on the canvas. 

Sketch Book renders as a fixed resolution output (1000x1200px). Controls (in live view): 

Press [2] to render at 2000x2400px
Press [4] to render at 4000x4800px
Press [8] to render at 8000x9600px
Press [s] to save the current view (default or higher resolution image)

metadata.name: cliques #50
metadata.description:
clique is defined as:

- /klƒìk,klik/ (n.) a small group of people, with shared interests or other features in common, who spend time together and do not readily allow others to join them.

cliques can offer safety. (something about numbers.)

cliques can offer a place to be. (for better or worse.)

sometimes cliques have sub-cliques. (the intersections can get a bit complicated.)

sometimes a member of a clique may still feel outside of it. (power dynamics can ruin things.)

occasionally clique dynamics are balanced and the connections between the members pull towards the center. (we can consider that non-toxic.)

often, though, the connections are pulled in various directions and the connection between two members are swayed (or pulled towards) other members. (we can consider that toxic.)

[4 color palettes: monochrome, neon, vibrant rebellion, glacier]

[tap ‚Äús‚Äù to save image]
[tip: zoom out to 25% first to save a higher res image]

[cc0] [p5js] [xoxo] [twitter: @heyjeres]

metadata.name: Artifice #26
metadata.description:
This series is is about playful obfuscation.

The fxtext article linked on the main profect goes more in-depth into what is meant by that, as well as the events that led to this collection.

5640 bytes of Vanilla JS with no libraries. Palettes make up a third of the code.

In live mode:
‚ÄòS‚Äô : save as png (3000‚Ää√ó‚Ää3600)
‚ÄôV‚Äô : save as svg (without grain)

URL params in live mode:
‚Äòg=n‚Äô : no grain
‚Äòg=p‚Äô : paper grain
‚Äòh=t‚Äô : high resolution mode, 9000‚Ää√ó10600 (Chrome only, and may take a moment)

For example, if you wanted paper grain in high resolution, append ‚Äú&g=p&h=t‚Äù to the url in live mode.

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save a png with those settings applied.

metadata.name: Haste Season #128
metadata.description:
‚ÄúDo not spoil the wonder with haste.‚Äù
‚Äï J.R.R. Tolkien, The Return of the King

This piece is here to point us to the fact that Haste season is upon us. It is the season when more people are moving than usual, and the dynamic movement of each person gives our world a wonderful composition. But it also increases the chance that something really bad will happen. Let's ensure that the chaotic image of cities, crowds, and haste that is before us becomes the perfect image of chaos. Image of people who love and respect one another. Image of wonder that we can be.

Made with P5js.
Bajiru, December 2022.

metadata.name: horizon(te)s #338
metadata.description:
For this collaboration we focused on horizons as an organizing principle.  What are the edges and borders of our vision and what do we see there?

Rather than create *one* collective piece where we mix our styles, we instead opted to create essentially a series of works ‚Äì focusing on our own personal responses to the prompt as well as how we imagine the other responding to the prompt.  Each of us took on three challenges as central modes: 

Me as me 
Me as you 
Me as you as me

Each mode has a variety of variations.  This framework allowed for speculation, ambiguity, and time to reflect on our own voice and the voice of our collaborator.   The idea was not to mimic styles but rather use this framework to try to have a conversation and explore what we see in each other‚Äôs work.   

Zach: 

For me as me, I created a series of block / glitch based images on a simple horizon.  I love creating color field compositions and often find myself staring at them ‚Äì especially the subtle and luminous ones.  They seemed well suited for exploring horizons.

For me as you, I focused on Iskra‚Äôs use of layers and simple geometry for creating compositions that reframe space.   I am a huge fan of her work ‚Äì especially how she elevates and uses simple geometry and creates ambiguous forms that reference architectural structures so I enjoyed exploring what I could do with a constraint of just using rectangles.   I see blocks, windows and portals.  

For me as you as me, I explored light.   Although Iskra‚Äôs compositions often use densely overlapped lines and forms there is often a really luminous and airy quality to her works that I deeply resonate with.  She creates curtains and shapes we can see through and I tried to imagine a form of light curtain that Iskra would create to generate my work.  In this mode, a set of color bands are organized along a horizon and overlap to create new spaces and forms. 

Iskra:

Working with Zach has been a challenge and a trigger to go beyond my own expectations, limits and the technology itself. Once we made the decision of splitting the work into these three approaches we basically focused on knowing better each one and our work.

Starting with the most difficult mode for me ‚ÄúMe as you ‚Äù (How could I recreate the magic lights of Zach?)  After some integration work, I got into something minimal and played with colors, contrast and shadows to recreate this feelight of shine, in my case using just lines. 

For ‚ÄúMe as you as me‚Äù I came up immediately with the idea of candies. Not sure why, but somehow I found colors and positive vibes very much associated with Zach‚Äôs work and I tried to recreate this idea by playing with sparks, flashes and vivid tones.

Last, ‚ÄúMe as Me‚Äù has been like my safe space. I changed easily through more than 5 different systems before getting the right one. The whole project is about Horizons and the idea of divisions, so I decided to focus on the concept of sea. Either a port or a mystic sailing boat, both have some disturbing elements in the scene. Sometimes a mesh ‚Äìis it possible to reflect this smell of iron? And sometimes an undefined stone cave ‚Äì is it there to protect us, or to attack us?

-----------

Artist notes  ‚Äì

Notes by Iskra: 

I highly recommend using Chrome for my pieces, especially for high res and downloads. Other browsers as Firefox or Safari have sometimes difficulties to display the work properly due to the structure of thin lines, compositions and overlaps of many of the outputs. 

Notes by Zach: 

My sketches require webgl and a relatively newer / modern browser.   Best / optimized for desktop.

For high resolution and saving on all modes ‚Äì
Press ‚Äúh‚Äù to set a high resolution mode.  Alternatively, press ‚Äúm‚Äù to increase the resolution until you want (or until your device allows it) and ‚Äúl‚Äù to reduce it. Use ‚Äús‚Äù to save the current resolution.

metadata.name: abstraction #16
metadata.description:
Diagrams of patterns on spheres, planets, fields, and platonic solids rendered isometrically. Ink on paper (on js).

Press DOWN to save an SVG suitable for plotting (or laser etching).
Press UP to save a 2400 x 2400 png. If you need a bigger image, zoom out and refresh, the canvas will fit the window.

Physics is fundamentally idealist. We search for simple rules from which the complexities of the universe emerge. But real systems are exceptionally complex, closed-form solutions are the exception. The deeper we dive into the fundamental nature of the universe, the less clear the rules become. Are the rules we've developed fundamental, or are they empirical approximations?

metadata.name: CSS Molecules #83
metadata.description:
This 3d animated work is composed almost completely of HTML + CSS. There is a limited amount of javascript to construct the scene and facilitate interactive controls. üö´ <canvas>!

A bit of history about this approach: As my first coding language HTML and CSS holds a special place in my heart. Even when I jumped into 3D my first creations were made with just some html + css coded in notepad. Earlier this year I took this idea to the next level with a yet-to-be-released 3D bedrooms project, filling it with objects and ever-refining my scene construction practice. This system for scene construction became the basis for a few other generative projects here on fxhash under my pseudonym htmlcss.tez. Here I abandon my usual representational focus with this technique and dive right into the abstract.

metadata.name: Absorbed #198
metadata.description:
A collaboration between leading British high-end audio brand KEF, generative artist hieroglyphica, and creative studio Parameta, Absorbed embodies the process of noise becoming high-fidelity sound through KEF‚Äôs Metamaterial Absorption Technology (MAT‚Ñ¢). 

MAT‚Ñ¢ makes the KEF sound what it is: absorbing unwanted distortion to deliver pure, accurate sound exactly as the artist intended. Inspired by this intricacy, Absorbed illustrates pseudorandom networks of patterns, slowly emerging and transforming into the maze-like form of MAT‚Ñ¢. Clarity is revealed, noise is absorbed ‚Äì high-fidelity is found.

The noise fields used in Absorbed are of two distinct types: conventional gradient noise and ‚Äúsinusoidal‚Äù noise, an original algorithm developed for this series. The use of animation as artistic medium reflects the artists‚Äô belief that no single frame can capture the full range of complexity found in the tension between sound and noise, and lets collectors observe for themselves this ever-shifting dialogue. A more extensive discussion of the algorithms used in Absorbed can be found in hieroglyphica‚Äôs companion article on fx(text).

- spacebar will pause and resume the animation
- s will save a still image of the current frame
- technically minded collectors can consult the index.html file for info on how to render and save high-resolution images
- use of hardware acceleration in Chrome may impact performance

Founded by BBC engineer Raymond Cooke in 1961, KEF is a leading British innovator of high-end audio products including HiFi speakers, subwoofers, architectural speakers, wireless speaker-systems, and headphones. Find out more at kef.com or visit our Discord at discord.com/invite/u48Z9yjY2q.

metadata.name: Papercut Factory #75
metadata.description:
Folding and cutting papers was one of my favorite papercraft activities in my childhood. Even when I grew up, I continued to use papercutting as a fun activity with my nieces to cut even more interesting shapes and push the limits of our imaginations.

In Papercut Factory, I tried to translate those memories into code, and as a result, into generative art, by creating an almost infinite number of variations.

The use of different shapes, color and quality of paper, varying grids, cut zones, random cut shapes, sizes and positions, background style and color resulted in millions or even billions of possible unique outcomes.

I hope that you will find something beautiful from your childhood in Papercut Factory ü§ó

* * *

Anyone who mints 4 or more pieces of Papercut Factory will receive 1 piece from my next drop as a gift.

Minters will receive 25% of royalties from secondary sales of their minted pieces.

* * *

Press S to save as PNG.

Made by: yenren / twitter.com/yenrenART
Made with: JavaScript + HTML Canvas
License: LICENSE.txt

metadata.name: Absorbed #217
metadata.description:
A collaboration between leading British high-end audio brand KEF, generative artist hieroglyphica, and creative studio Parameta, Absorbed embodies the process of noise becoming high-fidelity sound through KEF‚Äôs Metamaterial Absorption Technology (MAT‚Ñ¢). 

MAT‚Ñ¢ makes the KEF sound what it is: absorbing unwanted distortion to deliver pure, accurate sound exactly as the artist intended. Inspired by this intricacy, Absorbed illustrates pseudorandom networks of patterns, slowly emerging and transforming into the maze-like form of MAT‚Ñ¢. Clarity is revealed, noise is absorbed ‚Äì high-fidelity is found.

The noise fields used in Absorbed are of two distinct types: conventional gradient noise and ‚Äúsinusoidal‚Äù noise, an original algorithm developed for this series. The use of animation as artistic medium reflects the artists‚Äô belief that no single frame can capture the full range of complexity found in the tension between sound and noise, and lets collectors observe for themselves this ever-shifting dialogue. A more extensive discussion of the algorithms used in Absorbed can be found in hieroglyphica‚Äôs companion article on fx(text).

- spacebar will pause and resume the animation
- s will save a still image of the current frame
- technically minded collectors can consult the index.html file for info on how to render and save high-resolution images
- use of hardware acceleration in Chrome may impact performance

Founded by BBC engineer Raymond Cooke in 1961, KEF is a leading British innovator of high-end audio products including HiFi speakers, subwoofers, architectural speakers, wireless speaker-systems, and headphones. Find out more at kef.com or visit our Discord at discord.com/invite/u48Z9yjY2q.
